Specially Designed Instruction: Explicit, systematic phonics instruction using an Orton-Gillingham-based or equivalent structured literacy program (for example, Wilson Reading System, Barton Reading and Spelling, or UFLI Foundations), provided in a small-group setting (no more than 3 students) for a minimum of 30 minutes daily, 5 days per week, by a special education teacher trained in structured literacy methodology. Instruction will follow a systematic scope and sequence, incorporate multisensory techniques (visual, auditory, kinesthetic, tactile), include immediate corrective feedback, provide cumulative review of previously taught patterns, and use decodable texts that align with the patterns being taught. GOAL 2: MULTISYLLABIC WORD READING. Annual Goal: Given explicit instruction in syllable types and syllable division strategies, [Student] will accurately read multisyllabic words (2 and 3 syllables) containing closed, open, vowel-consonant-e, and vowel team syllable types with 80% accuracy on curriculum-based assessments, improving from a current baseline of 20% accuracy. Baseline: On a 20-word multisyllabic word reading assessment administered on [date], [Student] accurately read 4 out of 20 two- and three-syllable words (20%). [Student] does not currently demonstrate knowledge of syllable division rules and attempts to decode multisyllabic words by guessing based on the first letter or first syllable. Measurable Target: 80% accuracy (16 out of 20 words correct) on equivalent multisyllabic word reading assessments by the annual review date. Short-Term Objectives (Benchmarks): Benchmark 1 (End of Quarter 1): [Student] will identify the six syllable types (closed, open, VCe, vowel team, r-controlled, consonant-le) with 85% accuracy when presented with example words, and will accurately divide and decode 2-syllable words with closed syllables (rab/bit, nap/kin) with 70% accuracy (14/20). Benchmark 2 (End of Quarter 2): [Student] will accurately divide and decode 2-syllable words containing closed, open, and VCe syllable types with 75% accuracy (15/20). Benchmark 3 (End of Quarter 3): [Student] will accurately divide and decode 2- and 3-syllable words containing all practiced syllable types with 75% accuracy (15/20). Progress Monitoring: Administer a 20-word multisyllabic reading assessment every 2 weeks using equivalent word lists at the complexity level currently being instructed. Record accuracy and error patterns (which syllable types and division patterns cause the most difficulty). Review data monthly. Specially Designed Instruction: Direct instruction in syllable types and division rules integrated into the structured literacy program described in Goal 1. Use the REVLOC (or equivalent) mnemonic for syllable types. Teach syllable division patterns explicitly: VCCV (divide between consonants), VCV (try long vowel first, then short), VCCCV (divide keeping blends and digraphs together). Use manipulatives (syllable cards, magnetic tiles) for kinesthetic practice of dividing and recombining syllables. Practice with both real words and nonsense words to ensure application of rules rather than reliance on sight recognition. GOAL 3: ORAL READING FLUENCY. Annual Goal: Given evidence-based fluency instruction and regular practice with instructional-level text, [Student] will increase oral reading fluency on 2nd-grade-level text from a current baseline of 52 words per minute (91% accuracy) to 72 words per minute with at least 95% accuracy, as measured by curriculum-based measurement (CBM) oral reading fluency probes. Baseline: On DIBELS oral reading fluency probes administered on [date] (median of 3 probes), [Student] read 2nd-grade-level text at 52 words correct per minute (WCPM) with 91% accuracy. On 3rd-grade-level text, [Student] read 35 WCPM with 82% accuracy (frustrational level). The end-of-year 2nd-grade benchmark is approximately 87 WCPM, so [Student] is currently below the mid-year 2nd-grade benchmark. Measurable Target: 72 WCPM with 95% or greater accuracy on 2nd-grade-level CBM probes by the annual review date. This target represents a growth rate of approximately 1.5 words per week over 36 instructional weeks, which is an ambitious but achievable rate given intensive structured literacy intervention. Note: The target of 72 WCPM on 2nd-grade text is approximately at the mid-year 2nd-grade benchmark, reflecting that fluency gains in students with dyslexia are expected to lag behind typical grade-level expectations. The IEP team acknowledges that closing the grade-level gap fully within one year is not realistic, and that the priority is building foundational accuracy and automaticity that will support continued fluency growth in subsequent years. Short-Term Objectives (Benchmarks): Benchmark 1 (End of Quarter 1): [Student] will read 2nd-grade-level text at 57 WCPM with 93% accuracy. Benchmark 2 (End of Quarter 2): [Student] will read 2nd-grade-level text at 62 WCPM with 94% accuracy. Benchmark 3 (End of Quarter 3): [Student] will read 2nd-grade-level text at 67 WCPM with 95% accuracy. Progress Monitoring: Administer 3 DIBELS (or equivalent CBM) oral reading fluency probes at instructional level every 2 weeks. Record median WCPM and accuracy percentage. Graph results with aimline. If the trend line falls below the aimline for 3 consecutive assessment periods, adjust instructional strategies (increase practice frequency, modify text difficulty, or change fluency intervention approach). Specially Designed Instruction: Repeated reading with instructional-level decodable text (3 to 4 re-readings of the same passage with feedback), phrase-cued reading (text marked with phrase boundaries to promote prosody and reduce word-by-word reading), partner reading with a fluent peer model (peer reads first, student re-reads the same passage), whisper reading with teacher monitoring and error correction, and wide reading of high-interest, controlled-vocabulary texts at the student's independent level to build automaticity and reading volume. Fluency practice is integrated into the daily structured literacy block and supplemented with an additional 10 to 15 minutes of independent fluency practice using audio-assisted reading (student reads along with an audio recording of the text). GOAL 4: READING ENGAGEMENT AND SELF-ADVOCACY. Annual Goal: Given a structured independent reading program with choice, goal-setting, and self-monitoring supports, [Student] will independently sustain engagement with self-selected text at the independent reading level for a minimum of 12 consecutive minutes during daily independent reading time, and will voluntarily select reading as an activity during at least 2 out of 5 weekly choice periods, improving from a current baseline of 3 minutes of sustained reading and 0 out of 5 choice periods selecting reading. Additionally, [Student] will demonstrate self-advocacy by independently requesting accommodations (such as audio support, extra time, or text at an appropriate level) in at least 3 out of 4 observed opportunities when encountering frustrational-level reading tasks. Baseline: Teacher observation data collected over a 2-week period on [dates] indicates [Student] sustains independent reading engagement for an average of 3 minutes before becoming distracted, off-task, or requesting to switch activities. During 10 observed choice periods, [Student] selected reading as an activity 0 times. When given frustrational-level reading tasks, [Student] does not request help or accommodations, instead shutting down, putting head on desk, or engaging in avoidance behavior (sharpening pencils, bathroom requests) in 4 out of 4 observed opportunities. Measurable Targets: (a) 12 consecutive minutes of sustained engagement with self-selected text during independent reading time (measured by teacher observation using a time-on-task recording sheet, averaged over 5 observations per assessment period). (b) Voluntarily selects reading during at least 2 out of 5 weekly choice periods (measured by teacher choice-period log). (c) Independently requests appropriate accommodations in at least 3 out of 4 observed opportunities when encountering frustrational-level text (measured by teacher observation log). Short-Term Objectives (Benchmarks): Benchmark 1 (End of Quarter 1): [Student] will sustain reading engagement for 6 consecutive minutes and will select reading during at least 1 out of 5 choice periods. [Student] will identify and name at least 2 accommodations that help with reading (for example, audio support, reading a different level text). Benchmark 2 (End of Quarter 2): [Student] will sustain reading engagement for 8 consecutive minutes and will select reading during at least 1 out of 5 choice periods. [Student] will request an accommodation independently in at least 1 out of 4 opportunities. Benchmark 3 (End of Quarter 3): [Student] will sustain reading engagement for 10 consecutive minutes and will select reading during at least 2 out of 5 choice periods. [Student] will request an accommodation independently in at least 2 out of 4 opportunities. Progress Monitoring: Teacher records time-on-task data during independent reading periods weekly (minimum 2 observations per week, record sustained engagement duration). Teacher maintains a weekly log of choice-period selections. Teacher documents self-advocacy observations monthly (minimum 4 opportunities observed). Data reviewed monthly by IEP team. Specially Designed Instruction: Provide access to a curated classroom library with high-interest, low-readability texts (such as graphic novels, hi-lo readers, and series books) at [Student]'s independent reading level. Allow [Student] to self-select reading material within appropriate level range. Implement a reading goal-setting conference every 2 weeks where [Student] sets a personal reading goal (number of pages, minutes, or books) and tracks progress on a visual chart. Use positive reinforcement (praise, reading-related privileges) for incremental increases in reading engagement duration. Do not use punitive responses to avoidance behavior. Teach self-advocacy skills explicitly through role-playing scenarios: practice identifying when text is too hard (ask: Can I read most of the words? Do I understand what is happening?), practice requesting help or accommodations (sentence starters: 'This is really hard for me. Can I ___?'), and practice self-selecting appropriate-level text. Introduce audio-assisted reading options (text-to-speech on device, audiobooks paired with physical text) as a bridge strategy that allows [Student] to access grade-level content while building decoding skills. PROGRESS REPORTING. Progress toward all IEP goals will be reported to parents at the same frequency as general education report cards (quarterly). Progress reports will include current data compared to baseline and target, a graph showing the data trend, a narrative describing the student's response to instruction, and any recommended adjustments to goals, services, or strategies. ANNUAL REVIEW. Goals will be reviewed at the annual IEP meeting. At that time, the team will evaluate whether goals were met, partially met, or not met, review the effectiveness of the specially designed instruction, determine whether the current level and type of service remain appropriate, set new annual goals based on updated present levels, and consider whether additional assessments are needed.

prompt: Write a parent communication template for a middle school teacher to use when a student's academic performance has significantly declined. The student has gone from A/B grades to D/F grades over the past quarter, is missing assignments, and appears disengaged. Strike a tone that is concerned but not accusatory, and invite collaboration.
gold_answer: Subject: Checking In About [Student's First Name]'s Recent Progress. Dear [Parent/Guardian Name], I hope this message finds you well. I am reaching out because I want to share some observations about [Student's First Name]'s recent academic performance in my [Subject] class, and I would like to work together with you to support [him/her/them]. I want to start by saying that I know [Student's First Name] is a capable student. Earlier this year, [he/she/they] was earning A and B grades consistently and participating actively in class. That is why the changes I have noticed over the past several weeks have caught my attention, and I want to make sure we address them early while there is still plenty of time to get things back on track. Here is what I have been observing. Grade Change: [Student's First Name]'s overall grade has dropped from a [specific grade, e.g., B+] at the end of last quarter to a [specific grade, e.g., D-] currently. This represents a significant shift from [his/her/their] earlier performance. Missing Assignments: [Student's First Name] has [specific number, e.g., 7] missing or incomplete assignments over the past [timeframe, e.g., 4 weeks]. I have attached a list of these assignments with their due dates for your reference. In comparison, [he/she/they] had [0 or 1] missing assignments during the first quarter. Classroom Engagement: I have noticed that [Student's First Name] seems less engaged during class. [He/She/They] has been [describe specific observable behaviors: putting head down, not volunteering during discussions, working on other tasks during class time, appearing distracted or tired, etc.]. This is different from the [specific positive behaviors observed earlier: active participation, asking questions, helping peers, etc.] that I saw earlier in the year. I want to be clear that I am not writing to assign blame or create worry. Students go through periods where things get harder for a variety of reasons, including academic, social, emotional, or personal reasons, and I have seen many students work through these periods successfully when the adults in their lives notice and respond with support. I have already taken these steps on my end. I spoke privately with [Student's First Name] to let [him/her/them] know I have noticed the changes and that I care about [his/her/their] success. I offered [specific supports already provided, e.g., extra help during lunch on Tuesdays and Thursdays, extended deadlines for the missing assignments, a quiet workspace during study hall]. I checked in with [Student's First Name]'s other teachers to see if they are observing similar patterns. [Include brief summary if relevant: 'Several other teachers have noticed similar changes' or 'The changes seem most pronounced in my class.'] I would love to hear from you about what you are seeing at home and how [Student's First Name] is feeling about school right now. Sometimes students share things with their families that they do not share with teachers, and your perspective would help me understand how to best support [him/her/them]. I believe that when parents and teachers work as a team, students benefit the most. Here are a few things I would like to suggest as next steps. 1. A brief meeting or phone call: I would welcome the chance to talk with you in more detail about what we are both observing and to brainstorm a plan together. I am available [list 2-3 specific dates and times, e.g., Tuesday, March 5th from 3:30 to 4:00 PM, Wednesday, March 6th from 7:30 to 8:00 AM, or Thursday, March 7th from 3:30 to 4:00 PM]. If none of these times work, please suggest alternatives and I will do my best to accommodate. We can meet in person, by phone, or by video call, whichever is most convenient for you. 2. A plan for the missing work: I am willing to work with [Student's First Name] on a reasonable plan to complete the missing assignments. I want to focus on learning, not punishment, and I would rather [he/she/they] turn in work late than not at all. I can adjust deadlines if needed while we figure out what is going on. 3. An assignment tracker: I can set up a weekly email or update so that you can see what is assigned and what has been submitted. Some families find this helpful for staying connected to what is happening in class without having to rely solely on the student to communicate. I want you to know that I am on [Student's First Name]'s side. My goal is to help [him/her/them] succeed, and I know that starts with understanding what [he/she/they] might be going through right now. There is no judgment here, just genuine concern and a desire to help. If there is anything happening at home or outside of school that you think would be helpful for me to know (only what you are comfortable sharing), that context can help me provide better support in the classroom. Please feel free to reach out to me by email at [email address] or by phone at [phone number]. I typically respond to emails within 24 hours during the school week. Thank you for taking the time to read this. I look forward to hearing from you and working together to support [Student's First Name]. Warm regards, [Teacher Name]. [Subject] Teacher, [School Name]. prompt: Create a course syllabus outline for an undergraduate Introduction to Data Science course (one semester, 15 weeks). Include course description, learning outcomes, weekly topic schedule, grading policy, required tools/software, and academic integrity policy. The course should balance theory and hands-on practice.
gold_answer: COURSE SYLLABUS: Introduction to Data Science. Course Number: DS 201 (or CS 201 / STAT 201, cross-listed). Credits: 3 credit hours. Semester: [Semester Year]. Meeting Time: [Days] [Time] (e.g., Tuesday/Thursday 2:00-3:15 PM). Location: [Building/Room] and [online platform for hybrid sessions if applicable]. Instructor: [Name], [Title]. Email: [email]. Office: [Location]. Office Hours: [Days/Times, e.g., Monday and Wednesday 1:00-2:30 PM, or by appointment]. Teaching Assistant: [Name]. Email: [email]. TA Office Hours: [Days/Times]. COURSE DESCRIPTION. This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the field of data science, covering the full data analysis pipeline from data acquisition and cleaning through exploratory analysis, statistical modeling, machine learning, and communication of results. Students will develop practical skills in programming, data manipulation, visualization, and statistical thinking while building a conceptual understanding of the methods and ethical considerations that underpin modern data science practice. The course emphasizes hands-on learning through weekly labs, real-world datasets, and a culminating capstone project. By the end of the course, students will be able to independently conduct a complete data science investigation, from formulating a question to presenting actionable findings. No prior data science experience is required, though basic programming familiarity is expected. PREREQUISITES. Required: One introductory programming course (CS 101 or equivalent) in any language. Students should be comfortable with variables, loops, conditionals, and functions. Recommended (not required): One introductory statistics course (STAT 101 or equivalent). Students without statistics background will be supported with supplementary materials during the probability and inference unit. LEARNING OUTCOMES. Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. Import, clean, transform, and merge datasets from multiple sources and formats using Python and the pandas library. 2. Conduct exploratory data analysis (EDA) using summary statistics and data visualization to identify patterns, trends, anomalies, and relationships in data. 3. Apply fundamental statistical concepts including probability distributions, hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, and correlation to draw valid inferences from data. 4. Build, evaluate, and interpret supervised machine learning models (linear regression, logistic regression, decision trees, and random forests) for prediction and classification tasks. 5. Build and interpret unsupervised learning models (k-means clustering, principal component analysis) for pattern discovery. 6. Evaluate model performance using appropriate metrics (accuracy, precision, recall, F1, RMSE, R-squared) and techniques (train/test split, cross-validation) and identify overfitting. 7. Communicate data science findings effectively through clear visualizations, written reports, and oral presentations tailored to both technical and non-technical audiences. 8. Identify and discuss ethical considerations in data science including privacy, bias, fairness, and responsible use of data and algorithms. REQUIRED TOOLS AND SOFTWARE. Programming Language: Python 3.10 or later. Development Environment: Jupyter Notebook / JupyterLab (installed via Anaconda distribution). All students should install the Anaconda Individual Edition, which includes Python, Jupyter, and all required libraries. Key Libraries: pandas (data manipulation), NumPy (numerical computing), Matplotlib and Seaborn (visualization), scikit-learn (machine learning), SciPy (statistical functions), Statsmodels (statistical modeling). Version Control: Git and GitHub (free student account). All assignments will be submitted via GitHub Classroom. Textbook (Free/Open): 'Python Data Science Handbook' by Jake VanderPlas (available free online at jakevdp.github.io/PythonDataScienceHandbook). Supplementary: 'Think Stats' by Allen Downey (free online), course lecture notes and lab notebooks posted weekly on the course website. Hardware: A laptop capable of running Anaconda Python. All computationally intensive work can be done on Google Colab (free) if personal hardware is insufficient. WEEKLY TOPIC SCHEDULE. Week 1: Introduction to Data Science. Lecture: What is data science? The data science lifecycle. Types of data and data science roles. Real-world applications and case studies. Lab: Environment setup (Anaconda, Jupyter, Git/GitHub). Python review (data types, control flow, functions). First Jupyter notebook. Reading: VanderPlas Chapter 1. Week 2: Data Acquisition and Data Types. Lecture: Data sources (CSV, JSON, APIs, databases, web scraping). Structured versus unstructured data. Data types and schemas. Lab: Loading data from CSV and JSON files. Introduction to pandas: DataFrames, Series, indexing, and selection. Making API calls with the requests library. Reading: VanderPlas Chapter 3 (sections on pandas introduction). Week 3: Data Cleaning and Preparation. Lecture: The reality of messy data. Missing values (types of missingness: MCAR, MAR, MNAR). Handling duplicates, outliers, inconsistent formats, and data entry errors. Lab: Cleaning a real-world messy dataset. pandas methods: dropna, fillna, replace, astype, str methods. Data validation techniques. Assignment 1 Due: Environment setup and Python fundamentals. Week 4: Data Transformation and Feature Engineering. Lecture: Data transformation operations (filtering, sorting, grouping, aggregating, pivoting, melting). Merging and joining datasets. Creating new features from existing data. Lab: Advanced pandas: groupby, merge, join, pivot_table, melt. String manipulation and datetime handling. Feature engineering examples (extracting day of week, creating bins, one-hot encoding). Reading: VanderPlas Chapter 3 (continued). Week 5: Exploratory Data Analysis and Visualization I. Lecture: Principles of EDA. Summary statistics (mean, median, mode, standard deviation, percentiles, IQR). Distributions and shape. The grammar of graphics. Lab: Matplotlib fundamentals (figure, axes, plot types). Histograms, box plots, scatter plots, bar charts. Customizing plots (labels, titles, colors, legends). Assignment 2 Due: Data cleaning and transformation project. Week 6: Visualization II and Storytelling with Data. Lecture: Advanced visualization (heatmaps, pair plots, faceted plots). Visualization best practices and common pitfalls. Choosing the right chart type. Principles of effective data communication. Lab: Seaborn library (relplot, catplot, heatmap, pairplot). Interactive visualization introduction (Plotly basics). Building a multi-panel EDA dashboard for a dataset. Reading: Supplementary reading on data visualization principles. Week 7: Probability and Statistics Foundations. Lecture: Probability basics (rules, conditional probability, Bayes' theorem). Probability distributions (normal, binomial, Poisson). Sampling and the Central Limit Theorem. Lab: Simulating probability experiments in Python. Working with distributions using SciPy.stats. Sampling from populations and observing the CLT through simulation. Assignment 3 Due: Exploratory data analysis report. Week 8: Statistical Inference. Lecture: Hypothesis testing framework (null and alternative hypotheses, p-values, significance levels, Type I and Type II errors). Confidence intervals. t-tests, chi-squared tests, and ANOVA. Correlation versus causation. Lab: Conducting hypothesis tests in Python using SciPy. Calculating and interpreting confidence intervals. Correlation analysis and scatter plot interpretation. Midterm Exam: In-class midterm covering Weeks 1-7 (held during this week's lecture session). Week 9: Introduction to Machine Learning. Lecture: What is machine learning? Supervised versus unsupervised learning. The machine learning workflow: problem framing, data splitting, model training, evaluation. Overfitting and underfitting. Bias-variance tradeoff introduction. Lab: Introduction to scikit-learn. Train/test split. Building a first model (simple linear regression). Evaluating with metrics (RMSE, R-squared). Reading: VanderPlas Chapter 5 (introduction).
